title: How to Photograph Stained Glass

steps.headline: Ask if any wire meshes or other material protecting the stained glass can be temporarily removed.
steps.description: This way, you can photograph the glass without obstructions.

steps.headline: Put a white translucent sheet over the stained glass if too much sunlight is coming through it.
Climb a ladder or scaffolding as close to the stained glass as possible.
Position your camera directly opposite the stained glass.
steps.description: Start taking photos. This is a traditional method used to avoid seeing distortion in your stained glass pictures.

steps.headline: Move away from the stained glass you want to photograph.
steps.description: This technique works better with digital cameras.

steps.headline: Put a very long lens on your camera.
Zoom in towards the stained glass and take pictures.
steps.description: This should greatly reduce distortion in your photographs.

steps.headline: Put your camera on a tripod.
steps.description: Using a tripod prevents the occurrence of shaky pictures and can save you energy from holding a camera as still as possible.

steps.headline: Set your camera's self-timer for taking pictures of stained glass.
steps.description: This method will ensure that your camera does not experience any movement, even from a hand-pressed shutter button.

steps.headline: Use a small aperture setting for your camera.
steps.description: This is good for shooting stained glass that is high above you, such as a window. Using a small aperture will bring the top and bottom of the distant object's art into focus.

steps.headline: Set your camera's exposure metering.
steps.description: Generally, spot or center-weighted metering should be used. The better exposed a mid-tone color is, usually yellow or gold, in the stained glass photo will indicate how well the camera's spot or center-weighted exposure has been set.
